instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CHGR_BMON: What is CHGR_BMON? CHGR_BMON goes between the ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 that charges the battery & creates PPBUS_G3H and the SMC(system management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip) and provides current sensing information on battery charging to the SMC. If diagnostics reveal an off reading or failure with the charger current sense, this is a good place to start troubleshooting..
definitions.CHGR_AMON: What is CHGR_AMON? CHGR_AMON provides DC current sense information to the SMC(System management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip). It comes from the battery charging chip that controls the laptop charger, battery charging, and creation of PPBUS_G3H(ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip depending on the logic board part number and model). This is used for sensors. If a DC current sense sensor is reading off in diagnostics, this is a place to start looking. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
Was power cycling but after reflowing CD32's power cycling has stopped  
Amp meter shows 5.19v 0.02a
Has had liquid damage in the past as white markers are red.
No signs of corrosion

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.09v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 5.20v

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> resistance to ground = 14.52MOhms

I'm thing to replace the CD32's   ???

Thanks in advance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> resistance to ground = 14.52MOhms"
High value ohm readings don't help.
We need to know more about the power rail, apart of no short.
Use diode mode; only switch to ohm scale for very low values.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
I went ahead a replaced both CD32's but problem still persists

<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.28v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 5.20v 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.428v diode mode

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message: Check what happens with battery connected (known good battery).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message: Tried that. Still stuck at 5.19v  0.02a

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message: Was the diode mode reading for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> ok??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
Diode mode looks good.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage with battery connected?
Don't forget battery data cable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage with battery connected = 0.97v

Noticed that <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR_R</SIGNAL> = 5.20v  but <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> = 4.88v .  Does that sound correct to you???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
You've said to get correct <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, so 4.88V is good there.

Disconnect F7000 and check <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
With F7000 removed voltage at <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> = 0v

Bare in mind I only have charger plugged in and not battery

Could it be a bad <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> Rom chip? Does the ROM chip <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> W25Q80DVUXIE have to come from a donor or can it be purchased from places like mouser?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> has the frimware required for <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips and <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>.
Must come from donor board, or new one flashed with correct file.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message: What did you work out from the readings I gave you at <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR>? Where do I go from here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
I found a replacement <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> but it made no difference and besides, I think if it was the ROM I would have power cycling right?
Do you think it could be the HAL sensor or am I just unlucky and the two CD32's I bought new off ebay are crap??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
Should have a problem into <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area, as no voltage with battery too.
Post basic <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
Are these the readings you asked for? I wasn't to sure.

<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> - 1.29v
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL> - 5.13v
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDP</SIGNAL> - 5.13v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_BTN_L</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_BTN_R_L</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL> - 2.32v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL> - 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
Are these the readings you asked for? I wasn't to sure. These are without battery.

<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> - 1.29v
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL> - 5.13v
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDP</SIGNAL> - 5.13v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> - 0v"
I didn't ask for that one; please read correctly.
I used <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> internal notations; check the corresponding external ones.

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> gets steady 3V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>) - 5.20v
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL>) - 1.29v ,
VDDA (<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL>) - 5.13v
VDDP (<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDP</SIGNAL>) - 5.13v 
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>* (<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_R_L</SIGNAL>) - 0v
<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL>) - 2.32v 
AMON (<SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL>) - 0v 
BMON (<SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL>) - 0v 

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message: Just checked <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and it's now only showing 2.32v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message: Reball, or (better) change <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message: Waiting for stock. Will get back to you. Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message: Can a bad <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> pull down <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> ?
